item.title: Clustering Analysis
item.description: 6.1.1 Nbclust 6.1.2 ClustVis 6.1.3 Medusa 6.1.4 wcd 6.1.5 FUAT 6.1.6 hiplot 6.1.7 cola Unsupervised cluster analysis has been an integral part of transcriptomics, playing an important role in the identification of sub-groups or modelling to predict unknown samples. Breaking: Some well-used and comprehensive clustering tools are provided in this section. 6.1.1 Nbclust Introduction: The R package provides 30 indices which determine the number of clusters in a data set and it offers also the best clustering scheme from different results to the user.

item.title: Gene regulatory network analysis
item.description: 2.1.1 STRING 2.1.2 IMEx 2.1.3 IntAct 2.1.4 DIP 2.1.5 BioGRID 2.1.6 MINT 2.1.7 InnateDB 2.1.8 HuRI 2.1.9 InWeb 2.1.10 NDEx 2.1.11 IID 2.1.12 SIGNOR 2.1.13 MatrixDB 2.1.14 I2D 2.1.15 SPIKE Gene regulatory network (GRN) is the important mechanism of maintaining life process, controlling biochemical reaction and regulating compound level, which reveal the essential rules of a large number of biological processes and reactions in organisms. Breaking: Fifteen well-known gene/protein regulatory databases are cataloged, covering genes/proteins across species.

item.title: Knowledge Graph/text mining
item.description: 3.1.1 PubTator central 3.1.2 Phenomizer 3.1.3 BioGraph 3.1.4 WordCloud 3.1.5 BEST 3.1.6 iPTMnet 3.1.7 Genes2WordCloud 3.1.8 TeamTat 3.1.9 CADA 3.1.10 CROssBAR Mining valuable hidden knowledge from large-scale data relies on the support of reasoning technology. Knowledge graphs, as a new type of knowledge representation, have gained much attention in natural language processing. Knowledge graphs can effectively organize and represent knowledge so that it can be efficiently utilized in advanced applications.

item.title: Orthologous gene mapping across species
item.description: 1.1.1 biomaRt 1.1.2 homologene 1.1.3 g:Orth 1.1.4 OmaDB 1.1.5 EggNOG 1.1.6 OrthoVenn2 1.1.7 OrthoDB 1.1.8 ORCAN 1.1.9 KEGG Orthology 1.1.10 InParanoid 1.1.11 COG This document was provided to support the orthologous gene mapping across species (especially non-model taxa) for the downstream data analysis. Breaking: A summary of eleven R packages and web services tools, including the number of species, package installation, operating vignettes. 1.1.1 biomaRt Introduction: In recent years a wealth of biological data has become available in public data repositories.

item.title: Prediction of Potential Drug (Pharmocogenomics)
item.description: 4.1.1 Clue 4.1.2 CREEDS 4.1.3 L1000CDS² 4.1.4 PharmacoGx 4.1.5 DrugComboRanker 4.1.6 SEP-L1000 4.1.7 L1000FWD 4.1.8 Mantra 4.1.9 DvD 4.1.10 DSEA 4.1.11 cogena 4.1.12 gene2drug 4.1.13 DeSigN 4.1.14 ksRepo 4.1.15 iLINCS 4.1.16 Gene Expression Signature 4.1.17 PDOD 4.1.18 SigCom LINCS 4.1.19 DTX 4.1.20 Phosprof Drug repurposing (alternatively called “new uses for old drugs”) is a strategy for identifying new uses for approved or investigational drugs that are outside the scope of the original medical indication.

item.title: Spatial and temporal variation
item.description: 5.1.1 GEPIA 5.1.2 HumanBase-ExPecto 5.1.3 Expression Atlas 5.1.4 ToppCluster 5.1.5 GENT2 5.1.6 TISSUES 5.1.7 TissueEnrich 5.1.8 ORGANizer 5.1.9 deTS 5.1.10 WebCSEA 5.1.11 TEnGExA 5.1.12 Dynamic-BM 5.1.13 ADEIP The tissues or development stages of organisms have the common biological process, but the gene expression patterns of them are different, which means that different regulatory procedures control the specificity of the spatial and temporal variation. Understanding the specific expression and regulation of genes in spatial and temporal variation is helpful to better explore the genetic relationship and etiology of tissues and development stages, as well as to discover new specific therapeutic targets.

item.title: Survival Analysis
item.description: 7.1.1 UALCAN 7.1.2 survival 7.1.3 KM plotter 7.1.4 survminer Survival analysis is the study of survival times and of the factors that influence them. This method that requires extra documentation of time periods and events, has the potential to be used in a number of fields, such as ecology, medicine and botany. Breaking: Some user-friendly survival analysis tools are provided in this section. 7.1.1 UALCAN Introduction: UALCAN is a comprehensive, user-friendly, and interactive web resource for analyzing cancer OMICS data.

item.title: Discovering the cell markers
item.description: 5.2.1 CIERSORT 5.2.2 ESTIMATE 5.2.2 xCell 5.2.3 TIMER 5.2.4 MCPcounter 5.2.5 Bseq_SC 5.2.6 EPIC 5.2.7 quanTIseq 5.2.8 Abbas et al. 5.2.7 ABIS 5.2.8 ImmuCellAI 5.2.9 MuSiC 5.2.10 DeconRNASeq 5.2.11 Max Schelker et al. 5.2.12 DSA 5.2.13 singscore 5.2.13 Ting Gong et al. 5.2.14 PERT 5.2.14 ImmuCC 5.2.15 immunoStates 5.2.16 DCQ 5.2.17 SCDC 5.2.18 Edec 5.2.19 MMAD 5.2.20 scBio 5.2.21 debCAM 5.2.22 TEMT 5.2.23 DeMixT 5.2.24 Dtangle 5.2.25 FARDEEP 5.2.26 TOAST 5.

item.title: Gene ontology annotation
item.description: 1.2.1 WEGO 2.0 1.2.2 g:GOSt 1.2.3 agriGO 2.0 1.2.4 UniProtKB 1.2.5 PANTHER 1.2.6 GOrilla 1.2.7 WEGO 2.0 1.2.8 GOEAST 1.2.9 ShinyGO 1.2.10 GOTermFinder Gene Ontology project is established to standardized describe the gene product’s functional information and help the biologist answer the specific queries about gene function. The formal vocabulary about gene functions and products promotes a high level of annotation review integration from various databases. Breaking: A plethora of tools linking the Gene Ontology knowledgebase exist to annotate and visualize the genes function.

item.title: TF gene interaction database
item.description: 2.2.1 JASPAR 2.2.2 AnimalTFDB 2.2.3 CHEA 2.2.4 RegNetwork Transcription factors (TFs) are key regulators of intrinsic cellular processes, such as differentiation and development, and of the cellular response to external perturbation through signaling pathways. Most TFs recognize and bind to specific DNA sequences named as transcription factor biding sites, leading to specific spatiotemporal expression patterns of target genes. Breaking: Four TF target specific resources are collected. 2.2.1 JASPAR Introduction: JASPAR is a regularly maintained open-access database storing manually curated transcription factors (TF) binding profiles as position frequency matrices (PFMs).

item.title: Biological pathway annotation
item.description: 1.3.1 KEGG 1.3.2 Pathway ontology 1.3.3 Biocarta 1.3.4 Reactome 1.3.5 PANTHER 1.3.6 BioCyc 1.3.7 INOH 1.3.8 EHMN 1.3.9 WikiPathways 1.3.10 PID 1.3.11 Pathway Commons 1.3.12 SMPDB 1.3.13 Signalink 1.3.14 NetPath 1.3.15 iPAVS 1.3.16 ParmGKB 1.3.17 PathCards 1.3.18 ACSN 2.0 1.3.19 NDEx 1.3.20 SIGNOR 1.3.21 Plant Reactome 1.3.22 HAMdb 1.3.23 ComPath 1.3.24 BIOPYDB 1.3.25 PCxN 1.3.26 PathMe 1.3.27 pathDIP 1.3.28 PathBank 1.3.29 AOP 1.3.30 PathBIX Pathways are biological networks defining how biomolecules cooperate to accomplish cellular tasks in different conditions.

item.title: miRNA-gene interaction database
item.description: 2.3.1 TargetScan 2.3.2 miRBase 2.3.3 miRDB 2.3.4 RNAhybrid 2.3.5 miRTarbase 2.3.6 miR2Disease 2.3.7 TarBase 2.3.8 mirDIP miRNAs control the regulation of the majority of genes post-transcriptionally. Most miRNAs are involved in molecular pathways that influence inflammation, cell cycle regulation and carcinogenesis resulting in the onset or progression of pathological conditions. Investigating these interactions will be pivotal for understanding the etiology of pathologic processes, the potential new treatment strategies and for preventing diseases.

item.title: Tajectory inference
item.description: 5.3.1 slingshot 5.3.2 CellRank 5.3.3 CytoTree 5.3.4 VeloViz 5.3.5 Asc-Seurat 5.3.6 VeTra 5.3.7 TIMEOR 5.3.8 UniTVelo 5.3.9 TIPS 5.3.10 Velo-Predictor 5.3.11 ORIGINS 5.3.12 PAGA 5.3.13 SCORPIUS 5.3.14 STEMNET Trajectory inference aims at estimating dynamic changes in a single-cell transcriptome landscape, assuming that the cell-wise transcriptome is a static snapshot at a time point along some cellular process. The pseudotime and RNA velocity both are considered as the trajectory inference.Highly variable genes, represented by DEGs, thus contribute an important role in the pseudotime and RNA velocity analysis.

item.title: Cell communication
item.description: 5.4.1 IUPHAR 5.4.2 CellPhoneDB 5.4.3 FANTOM5 5.4.4 Cell-Cell Interaction Database 5.4.5 ligand-receptor pairs in literature 5.4.6 DLRP 5.4.7 ConnectomeDB 5.4.8 CellTalkDB 5.4.9 ICELLNET 5.4.10 Cellinker 5.4.11 PlantPhoneDB 5.4.12 CellCallEXT 5.4.13 CellChat 5.4.14 Giotto 5.4.15 SingleCellSignalR 5.4.16 CellCall 5.4.17 TraSig 5.4.18 celltalker 5.4.19 iTALK 5.4.20 PyMINEr 5.4.21 DeepCCI 5.4.22 NicheNet 5.4.23 SpaOTsc 5.4.24 CCCExplorer 5.4.25 SoptSC 5.4.26 NATMI 5.4.27 scConnect 5.4.28 FunRes 5.4.29 scTensor Cell communication across multiple cell types and tissues strictly mediates proper functioning of metazoans and extensively relies on interactions between secreted ligands and cell-surface receptors.

item.title: ceRNA-gene interaction database
item.description: 2.4.1 ENCODE 2.4.2 starBase 2.4.3 miRcode 2.4.4 DIANA-LncBase 2.4.5 OmniPath 2.4.6 ceRDB 2.4.7 LncACTdb 2.4.8 PceRBase Post-transcriptional crosstalk and communication between RNAs yield large regulatory competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA) networks via shared microRNAs. The ceRNA crosstalk represents a novel layer of gene regulation that controls both physiological and pathological processes such as development and complex diseases. Breaking: Eight ceRNA related databses are summarized in this section. 2.4.1 ENCODE Introduction: The ENCODE Portal, developed and maintained by the Data Coordination Center (ENCODE DCC), is the canonical source for all experimental metadata and data from ENCODE and associated projects.

item.title: Other gene annotation
item.description: 1.4.1 InterPro consortium database 1.4.2 UCSC Genome Browser database 1.4.3 MSigDB 1.4.4 HumanBase 1.4.5 DISGENET 1.4.6 VaProS 1.4.7 Autophagy Database 1.4.8 MitoCarta3.0 1.4.9 OMIM 1.4.10 HGMD 1.4.11 CancerSEA 1.4.12 The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) 1.4.13 GeneCards 1.4.14 GeneALaCart Interpreting the relationship between molecular mechanisms and phenotypes, in addition to the GO and pathway annotation, other functional attributes also provide a window into the genes, such as, diseases-associated gene annotations, human/mouse phenotypes, hallmark genes, oncogenic signature, immunologic signature, cell type signature, chromosome cytoband, subcellular locations, developmental stage, gene variant, literatures, domains annotaions, etc.

item.title: Analysis and Visualization Tools
item.description: 2.5.1 GeneMANIA 2.5.2 NetworkAnalyst 2.5.3 ConsensusPathDB 2.5.4 iRegulon 2.5.5 NAViGaTOR 2.5.6 FunCoup 2.5.7 miRTargetLink 2.5.8 FFLtool For the construction of regulatory networks, in addition to the development of diverse databases, tools for visualizing networks are important methods for mining and presenting gene networks. Breaking: Eight popular network visualization and module analysis tools are recommended, and those tools may predict and visualize gene-gene, TF-gene, MiRNA-gene, ceRNA, etc. 2.5.1 GeneMANIA Introduction: GeneMANIA finds other genes that are related to a set of input genes, using a very large set of functional association data.
